column830: **Update 6.24.14**My 128 GB card stopped allowing writes via any of my card-readers Windows PC--either when was inside any of several full-size SD card adapters (with write-protect tab either position) plugged directly into microSD slot of reader. MicroSD cards have no write-protect tab so was quite surprised worried by this. After failing to find any workable solution by searching online finally put my Chromebook created new folder there then stuck back my Windows PC no longer gave me write-protect error. If anyone has similar problem I'd recommend doing something similar by putting any other PC laptop camera etc have available try writing to there.----------------------------------------------This portion of my review necessarily being written as update to my original review of 64 GB version of card since Amazon disallows multiple reviews for what consider same item. portion concerns 128 GB version of card:I don't need fast card so speeds card not important besides which my test PC not exactly high-end. Therefore didn't count off for speed results got below using USB 2.0 card adapter thought might relevant to some readers. While card did reach Class-10 and/or UHS-I requirements came under 2/3 of claimed "read speeds up to 30 MB/s for fast file transfer." Then again running second PC using different USB 2.0 card reader none of speeds even hit 5 MB/s so seems to highly system-dependent.I only got card week so far works *select* SDXC-compatible devices exFAT-compatible operating systems: some SDXC-compatible devices such as Panasonic HDC-TM40 do not allow cards larger than 64 GB (for whatever reason); was stated manual confirmed card recognized as broken/corrupt/unusable device whereas 64 GB exFAT cards work fine. The 128 GB works fine (with original exFAT formatting) my Toshiba Excite 7.7 Android tablet (predictably) not all my non-SDXC-compatible Galaxy Note 2 (though it possibly would if reformatted to FAT32 since 64 GB card FAT32 works fine there).I'll update my review to reflect any problems issues etc notice the coming days & weeks.-----------------------------------------------------------------------CrystalDiskMark 3.0.3 (C) 2007-2013 hiyohiyoCrystal Dew World : [url removed as per Amazon rules]-----------------------------------------------------------------------* MB/s = 1000000 byte/s [SATA/300 = 300000000 byte/s]Sequential Read : 18.694 MB/sSequential Write : 11.921 MB/sRandom Read 512KB : 18.502 MB/sRandom Write 512KB : 0.680 MB/sRandom Read 4KB (QD=1) : 3.339 MB/s [ 815.1 IOPS]Random Write 4KB (QD=1) : 1.581 MB/s [ 386.1 IOPS]Random Read 4KB (QD=32) : 3.151 MB/s [ 769.4 IOPS]Random Write 4KB (QD=32) : 1.564 MB/s [ 381.8 IOPS]Test : 1000 MB [G: 0.0% (0.0/119.1 GB)] (x5)Date : 2014/04/24 16:53:49OS : Windows XP Professional SP3 [5.1 Build 2600] (x86)-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------The following my original review of the 64 GB version of card published April 24 2013:This high-quality card. I've used it in variety of devices through multiple readers different pcs in an HD camcorder using a micro to full-sized SD adapter I've never once had a problem it. even works full capacity in *some* microSDHC-only devices once its reformatted to FAT32 (such as my SanDisk Clip+ FLAC player supposedly even PSPs via a proper adapter though I haven't yet tested my PSP). I keep anticipating someone coming out a card equal better capacity speeds at a comparable price I haven't seen one yet. If these cheaper I'd have several by now.Make sure your device can handle micro full-sized SDXC cards is one of those rare gems that state support only as high as SDHC have been tested to work SDXC cards such as this one once they've been manually reformatted to FAT32.

For most of cruise was using my DSLR next time wanted to use my cell phone phone told me had no memory card loaded. Any way tested card my laptop when got back couldn't recognize contacted SanDisk via email provide them copy of my receipt Amazon along serial number back of card (very hard to read) no problems; told me to send them back card they sent me brand new card which now still functioning my cell phone. Great support provide by SanDisk. No hassle as long as can provide proof of purchase (easy to do since Amazon keeps my entire purchase history/invoices online). One reason buy directly Amazon itself vs other vendors (either Amazon elsewhere Internet) have confidence memory cards sold by Amazon itself genuine. there may incredible deals elsewhere internet some cases deals too good to true counterfeit cards being sold.Original review:Just received today. Removed from the packaging inserted into my Samsung Galaxy S3 (Verizon) powered the unit back up the storage was available. No formatting required. Worked the first time out. Settings showed 29.71GB of total space (32GB version) 29.71GB of free space. like the fact that SD adapter came it. Should ever need to insert the card into my laptop will come in handy. (yes can plug my phone directly to my laptop if ever swap 32GB card out of my phone replace it with a 64GB version I can use 32GB version via the adapter for other purposes.)

column1335: Still don't feel very fast is my phone guess will need to remove and run some R/W tests. Still Its ok.
column1346: bought 64GB version of card to use GoPro Hero 3 black edition. didn't work out. The card worked OK if camera set to resolution lower bit rates. E.g. worked fine 720p protune or 1080p protune off. However 1080p protune (bitrate shy of 6 MB/s mode -- much higher then protune turned off) nothing trouble. Camera would sometime work sometime randomly stop recording for no obvious reason. first suspected camera testing different SD cards ended up being SanDisk's card fault. My spare card old cheap 16GB PNY (also class 10) worked fine under same conditions same camera settings.Once obvious problem card found people GoPro's forums had trouble specific card as well (well always find these only after figure out for yourself right?). Anyhow did some speed tests card by doing simple write of 1GB file full of zeros using Unix dd utility to copy 1GB of zeros /dev/zero (where else would find many zeros ;-) onto file card. The result was average SanDisk's card would manage about 10.2 MB/s. Just barely above bar for class 10 card. However was average over 1GB. During write test speed was oscillating many spikes drops. Drops as low as 7MB/s. Uh. thought write speed of class 10 card should never dip below 10 MB/s? For comparison my old cheap class 10 PNY card was chugging along constant 13 MB/s under same test. No spikes no drops speed.The card will probably work fine most devices as bitrates when recording 1080p video often low enough and/or camera might have huge buffer. if want to use to record video high bitrates your device doesn't have huge buffer to compensate for speed bumps of this card may run into trouble. Be wary of using Hero3 modes have higher bit rates (e.g. 1080p protune enabled).SanDisk's website lists part numbers as SDSDQUI-064G adapter SDSDQUA-064G without adapter. conflicts product description Amazon. While this likely just Amazon not getting product description right again (a bit too common thing) it's interesting to note.[Update Apr 20 2013]:Some numbers testing card. The test extremely simple. Write out 1GB of zeros onto card using standard Unix dd command to read 128KB blocks of zeroes special device /dev/zero write onto card. 128KB * 8192 = 1GB. dd displays transfer stats once finishes. While dd was running run iostat second terminal displaying 1 second interval stats as measure of current speed. was done the Mac. dd command line can used as-is to repeat test Linux system however iostat command different Linux would need to modified slightly. choose 128KB block size as that seems to what device drivers merges sequential writes into anyhow. Using different block sizes results comparable.$ dd if=/dev/zero of=test bs=131072 count=81928192+0 records in8192+0 records out1073741824 bytes transferred 101.578307 secs (10570582 bytes/sec)So 10 MB/s all good? Right? Wrong! iostat running parallel with above dd command recorded this:$ iostat -d -w 1 disk2disk2KB/t tps MB/s123.11 76 9.12116.61 185 21.04122.94 49 5.88128.00 41 5.12128.00 89 11.11128.00 134 16.73128.00 69 8.61128.00 61 7.62128.00 99 12.36[ and so until dd finishes writing 1GB of zeros to the card ]IMO the last column should never dip under 10MB/s for card labeled class-10.For comparison same test run against Samsung Pro 64GB micro-SD card:$ dd if=/dev/zero of=test bs=131072 count=81928192+0 records in8192+0 records out1073741824 bytes transferred in 52.869111 secs (20309436 bytes/sec)$ iostat -d -w 1 disk2disk2KB/t tps MB/s125.30 138 16.86117.73 157 18.03123.04 150 18.00128.00 159 19.86128.00 156 19.47126.45 160 19.73128.00 150 18.72128.00 154 19.22128.00 153 19.11[ and so until dd finishes writing 1GB of zeros to the card ]So Samsung on average 2x faster more importantly it's speed is much more constant. And critically important never dips under 10MB/s."

These 64GB versions don't seem to have formatting issues the 32GB ones do even then formatting to FAT32 fixes it.

column2039: My Samsung Galaxy Note 2 came 8 gigs of internal memory. discovered apps can only written to internal 8 gigs of memory so didn't want to fill up internal memory pictures videos music etc. purchased 64 GB San Disk Ultra MicroSDXC Class 10 card. found video youtube to learn how to insert card since could find nothing phone's user guide. It's real easy. Turn Note phone off. Remove Note's back plate. You see plaque saying SD card upper left quadrant of phone. Simply place microsd card face up metallic pins facing down towards right into depressed slot area to left of SD card plaque. Then slowly gently slide microsd card under plaque until clicks. If isn't correctly will tend to move back out under plaque. Do not force. Replace back plate phone. Turn phone on. Go to settings storage. At bottom of page will see SD Card. If microsd card inserted correctly will see additional GBs of storage displayed there. You will also see Reformat SD card Remove SD card. Use these settings to erase data microsd card to remove it the phone. Do not try to remove the microsd card from the phone without first activating the Remove SD Card setting. You can damage the card the phone. The card came quickly San Disk a reliable brand. It's great to have the Class 10 rating too.

column3447: Bought card to use my Samsung Galaxy Tab2 7in tablet based others who have reported getting to work their Galaxy Tab 2.Bottom line gotta reformat card as FAT32 32kb sectors to work Galaxy Tab 2 requires jumping thru some hoops as Win6/Vista does not even offer choice to format as FAT32 only as NTFS exFAT neither of which will work Galaxy Tab 2 (Android v4.04) You have to use 3rd party software to accomplish this. column3952: It so hard to imagine can have 32 GB something smaller than postage stamp yet is.I bought card to work my Call of Duty Ghosts Tactical Camera it works perfectly. The camera came 4 G card which filled just over hour local Kart track. missed last bit of our race due to insufficient capacity. The battery still going strong so needed more card for recording my adventures.This card fits bill nicely.As UHS Speed Class 1 (roughly equiv Class 10) card SD card quite capable of any photographic video need up to Full HD (not 2k 4k). use similar card my Canon 60D am able to hold around 700 raw images few hours of HD video.Here some benchmarks for comparison including card.MacBook Pro Retina SSD430 MB/s write323 MB/s readGeneric Class 6 4GB (Came Ghost Camera)9.8 MB/s write21 MB/s readSanDisk Extreme Class 10 8GB21 MB/s write23 MB/s readThis Card San Disk Ultra UHC 112 MB/s write45 MB/s readWhat does mean? means should have no trouble recording HD video reliably card. Your camera will able to save pictures quickly to card so it is ready to take next shot. If fill card it will take roughly 12 minutes to copy all data off of card assuming device are copying to can keep up.The tests done built SD card drive of MacBook Pro using the included SD Card Adapter.Based my tests would say if don't need Micro SD then should buy standard SD card your performance might better the price should lower. However if you think you need might need a Micro SD down the road this is a suitable solution.

column7339: I'm music lover like to carry my entire music collection around me everywhere go. That being said takes up LOT of space enough to fill 64gb memory card its own (a lot of files FLAC format.) little hesitant to buy 128gb card when came out recently because 64gb cards first batch pretty much defective resulted recall. Me learning of recall after looking up issues was having had to return card bought. SanDisk took 64gb card back without hesitation was actually prepared to do without serial number (since couldn't open my phone time because case screwed on.)Note to everyone:Quite few applications don't fully support NTFS newer file system formats such as exFAT. To use your SD card without issues have to format to FAT32 which IS possible even though its over 32GB. Use "Fat32Format" tool made by Ridgecrop Consultants there's GUI (Graphical User Interface) version available for those unfamiliar using the command line.------After receiving my new card formatted to fat32 since use a lot of applications aren't the norm it's easier to use older file system compatible everything made after 1996. The transfer of files swapping of cards was seamless my computer's micro-sd card reader recognized without trouble as well as my phone. far everything is good there's been no hiccups. Even Google Play has been crashing less when trying to browse my music collection.

column7922: The description Amazon page calls a class 10 card UHS-1 performance. And while technically correct (Full HD 1080p recording). You would expect more performance Sequential Write speeds. actually doesn't even hit class 10 speed unless round up (9.951 MB/s). have 2 of these cards they both report same speed. My Kingston 8GB SDHC Class 4 writes 11.854 MB/s. Now keep mind Sandisk beats other cards random reads writes. maybe design for those faster random reads writes causes the sequential writes to run slower than expected. Here the test for the San Disk followed by the Kingston-----------------------------------------------------------------------CrystalDiskMark 3.0.2 (C) 2007-2013 hiyohiyoCrystal Dew World : [...]-----------------------------------------------------------------------Sandisk Ultra 16GB Class 10 Micro SDHC (UHS Speed?)* MB/s = 1000000 byte/s [SATA/300 = 300000000 byte/s]Sequential Read : 20.651 MB/sSequential Write : 9.951 MB/sRandom Read 512KB : 20.191 MB/sRandom Write 512KB : 2.628 MB/sRandom Read 4KB (QD=1) : 3.656 MB/s [ 892.5 IOPS]Random Write 4KB (QD=1) : 1.665 MB/s [ 406.4 IOPS]Random Read 4KB (QD=32) : 3.293 MB/s [ 803.9 IOPS]Random Write 4KB (QD=32) : 1.618 MB/s [ 395.0 IOPS]Test : 1000 MB [F: 0.0% (0.0/14.8 GB)] (x1)Date : 2013/03/26 21:28:09OS : Windows 7 Home Premium Edition SP1 [6.1 Build 7601] (x64)=======================================================================-----------------------------------------------------------------------CrystalDiskMark 3.0.2 x64 (C) 2007-2013 hiyohiyoCrystal Dew World : [...]-----------------------------------------------------------------------Kingston 8GB SDHC Class 4* MB/s = 1000000 byte/s [SATA/300 = 300000000 byte/s]Sequential Read : 20.287 MB/sSequential Write : 11.854 MB/sRandom Read 512KB : 19.925 MB/sRandom Write 512KB : 1.728 MB/sRandom Read 4KB (QD=1) : 3.747 MB/s [ 914.7 IOPS]Random Write 4KB (QD=1) : 0.017 MB/s [ 4.2 IOPS]Random Read 4KB (QD=32) : 3.684 MB/s [ 899.5 IOPS]Random Write 4KB (QD=32) : 0.017 MB/s [ 4.3 IOPS]Test : 1000 MB [F: 53.3% (4047.8/7592.0 MB)] (x1)Date : 2013/03/27 10:48:56OS : Windows 7 Home Premium Edition SP1 [6.1 Build 7601] (x64)

column9451: The advertisement calls card "class 10" card however was not able to get "class 10" speeds card. These small memory cards seem to very limited their write speed. Also card did heat up some when transferring to for long period of time continuously not too bad...just warm. The read speeds seem to cap out about 18MB/s did see 25MB/s small files. One to note may by design for particular card card super fast when transferring small files slow big files so you'll see slower write speeds longer write to with larger files whereas smaller files zip along one time that 10MB/s. was getting 8.6MB/s when writing a 4.6GB movie file to card. All all this excellent card beyond worth money for what get. love for my EVO 4G LTE my previous phone EVO 4G. The only reason gave 4 stars is because did not perform as advertised 30MB/s. column11585: Of late Sandisk appears to have lost their way little their flash storage products. It's almost universal truth all of their USB flash drives hopelessly slow; while they're usually reliable transfer rates of 4MB/sec less worthless when filling 32GB drive. Fortunately their "Ultra" line of SD cards still appears to buck trend.Formatted as NTFS used anelago Mobile Nano II reader see write speeds 64-bit Linux machine consistent 15-16MB/sec when copying large (1GB larger) files to card which more than lives up to its class 10 billing. Reads appear to run about 19-20MB/sec.I can't comment reliability as only had card few days everything copied so far for testing has made onto card (and off again) no corruption whatsoever; MD5 checksum of every file transferred matches source. That's more than can said for Supertalent Pico USB drive SD card reader intended to replace which has never been quite right (it's always occasionally randomly corrupted files of larger than 100MB so probability of 1GB greater files surviving near zero).32GB appears to sweet spot moment; smaller cards don't cost much less larger cards beyond SDHC spec into SDXC territory which isn't yet universal terms of device compatibility (not to mention cost far more than double for 64GB).For what paid for around Thanksgiving (not part of any explicit sale definitely lower price than appears usual as far as camelcamelcamel concerned) extremely satisfied.Edit: should also mention the included mechanical full-size SD adaptor one of the worst ever encountered. There's lot of friction when the microSD card inserted it's a right bugger to get out of the adaptor again. Thankfully have a few other such adaptors lying around should ever need one; this one's going the bin.

column12201: bought two of these 128 gb MicroSD cards which formatted to Fat32 currently have about 62 gb 35000 files each card. carry one card my wallet keep one safe deposit off-site. been through SanDisk literature looking to see if there any restrictions their use other than as ordinary "flash memory" for file storage. There no restrictions could find. What have found these 128 gb cards (and SanDisk 64 gb card bought previously) cannot accept 62 gb of data written a computer without suffering errors. had to resort to copying no more than 1/3 gb of data a time to these cards stopping then starting another 1/3 gb until complete data copied. The errors actually occur early at approximately 2 to 3 gb point. I have several other 128 gb flash memory sticks - Lexar Echo series as well as a hundred other lower-capacity flash memory cards do not have overflow/error problem any of those. To repeat there no restrictions the use of these memory cards (example: can used only a camera) given by SanDisk given that the 62 gb of data each card has been verified as to integrity are not defective."

column12926: purchased two of these microSDXC cards when sale around Black Friday have been using them now for about two months. They work wonderfully I have had no problems either. These SanDisk memory cards 64 GB microSDXC class 10 UHS-1 cards which rated for transfer speeds up to 30MB/sec.The UHS class 1 designation intended as performance measure indicates card capable of supporting real-time full HD video recording. Of course only works if using device which capable of writing to card those speeds most modern devices offer full HD recording such as camcorders digital SLR cameras cell phones built Full HD recording do support standard. The benefit of using UHS-1 card a UHS certified device should not encounter problem of buffering your device stopping recording because could not write fast enough.However because these are extra high capacity sdXC cards will need to make sure your device can support microSDXC cards not simply microSD microSDHC ones. The biggest difference microSDXC standard uses exFAT file system rather than FAT32 NTFS systems. While most modern Android devices (and fact most linux/unix devices) can handle that without difficulty some devices such as older cameras Android devices some Windows devices may have difficulty the format.Having said that I've been using these Nikon D80 & D7000 digital SLR cameras as well as Samsung Galaxy S3 Galaxy S Relay 4G phones without any difficulty they read & write fine my computers. All all these were a great buy I'm happy them."

column13717: Although Amazon claim C10 ultra fast Memory Card actually has much slower write speed than other C10 microSD card (it only scores about 60% of normal speed). For example have tested against my old Maxell C10 HC microSD card. The test done by writing same 3035MB random data DRAM to empty microSD card through USB3 card reader. The resulting time average value 3 tests of each device:SanDisk Ultra 32GB C10/UHS1: 5m50.816s means 8.7MB/sMaxell C10 HC: 3m38.787s means 13.9MB/sThe speed is completely unacceptable for Class-10 claim (13% lower than 10MB/s lowest boundary of Class-10 device) even the over-advertisement of SD card speeds common (claiming 30MB/s for actual 12-15MB/s). is almost scam. Some Class-6 card will beat "Class-10" card.

column15157: purchased Ultra MicroSDHC Class 10 card for my media player. wanted to replace my 4GB cardwith one so could store more music. to have wide range of music to pick when amon vacation traveling an airplane long distances. think may have bought too much.This card advertised as water-proof temperature proof X-ray proof shock proof. will have totake their word for am not going to test it.Just for fun put 16GB MicroSDHC disc (30MB/s Read Speed) into its provided adapter used itin my cheapo cheapo Toshiba Camileo HD movie camera. Even Full High Definition resolution of1080p/30fps disc performed well. No stuttering no missed frames all under low lightconditions. Nice. Very Nice. Those big files Full HD resolution. Read on...This card 'USH-1' enabled which means fastest card available (allegedly) should reachup to bus interface speed of 104 MB/s; if electronic device using requires Of courseif your card reader device does not support speed will transferring data your usualspeed. Sort of like saying backward compatible don't expect blazing speeds. You can feeddata through only so fast.Transferring RAW photos Full HD digital film can take lot of time to transfer. Those hugefiles to transfer so USH-I enabled disc perfect for purpose. They working USH-IIwhich is supposed to allow up to 300MB/s transfers. Talk about instant gratification we are aboutthere.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Here is guide by 'SD Association' regard to Class ratings video applications:> Class 2 for SD video recording> Class 4 6 for high-definition video (HD) to Full HD video recording> Class 10 for Full HD video recording consecutive recording of HD stills> UHS Speed Grade 1 for real-time broadcasts large HD video files> UHS Speed Grade 3 for 4K video files-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------USH-I overkill for media player? Probably for price was terrific deal to get Class 10USH-1 enabled card have flexibility to use a variety of my electronic devices. Hmm. Onsecond thought may keep card for movie camera get another ""slower"" one for mymedia player.As usual I have had no problems card. Works well or out of the adapter seems verytough in it's construction. 5 stars for this little power house of a micro card."

column19368: SanDisk Ultra Class 10 micro SDHC card (16GB 32GB 64GB)I purchased 32GB card for my Samsung Galaxy S3 16GB card for another video recording device. formatted both cards FAT32 using Windows 7 functioned without drama respective devices. purchased 64GB for my GoPro Hero3 Silver edition.The reason chose SanDisk Ultra for Class 10 speed rating as well as waterproof shockproof vibration proof X-ray proof durability. had 32GB Sandisk fail after 2 months of easy usage my Samsung Galaxy S3. don't abuse my phone not subject to extreme temperature/vibrations. Sandisk replaced under warranty it quite hassle to do this.The 16GB card however has been subject to extreme temperatures for well over 4 months: -5F to 100F doesn't include solar loading sitting under sun as well as 100% humidity! The 16GB card dripping water after experienced water intrusion one of my cameras it had been soaked water (while operating) for several months.The packaging easy to open by simply cutting across top. However finagling out the blister pack took some patience. The Frustration Free packaging essentially cardboard envelope sleeve plastic holder the SD card adapter microSD card inside. how it is shipped!Overall: 4/5 stars. Very affordable decently fast micro SD cards. These perfect for smartphones recording devices used extreme environments. However one of them failed within 2 months. The speeds also inconsistent. posted a benchmark photo Amazon showing my speeds all 3 sizes of cards the 32GB the fastest.UPDATE 28 OCT 2012My 32GB card has failed after over 2 months of use my Samsung Galaxy S3 phone. started dismounting/remounting intermittently by itself over night. woke up morning to find that the card is not readable via the phone wouldn't work my PC. The phone has not been abused not used an extreme environment. card was replaced under warranty by Sandisk.

column21831: have read many places would not work Android tablets have found card requires to format Windows computer to get to work. Even tablets are rated to 32GB have been found to read / write this card to 64GB. You need to download a free partitioning program format using to FAT32. First erase current partition then repartition to 64GB then format. You can't simply use Windows to format to FAT32 newer Windows computers even older Vista max will allow 32GB FAT32. Using partitioning software bypasses 32GB limit formats whole card so when after insert into tablet reads something 59.4GB formatted space. Huge capacity for the money a FAST card. Search internet for formatting 64GB microSD card for Android read up it."

column22172: UPDATE 6/18/14: suppose nothing lasts forever. After almost year card has gone bad. use card lot my smartphone - T-Mobile Samsung Galaxy S3 (SGH-T999). Then deleted video decided to download directly to my phone not SD card - EUREKA. played perfectly.I formatted SDXC card twice - once phone once through Windows - tried same test. Downloaded video file to card then to the phone. Same result both times - wouldn't play the SD card did the phone. All videos used to play perfectly the SD card. column22315: [[ UPDATE - 6/19/2014 ]]So my lovely wife bought me Samsung Galaxy Tab 4 for Father's Day I've been loving ever since. Just as other Samsung products Galaxy Tab 4 has ability to add microSD card to expand memory device. Since it's been over year decided to do some more research to see if SanDisk offered anything new. As of 6/19/2014 their product lineup for microSD cards worst to best (performance-wise) as follows:SanDiskSanDisk UltraSanDisk Ultra PLUSSanDisk ExtremeSanDisk Extreme PLUSSanDisk Extreme PRONow difference between all of these cards simply speed which can read/write data to card. Yes published rating of most all these cards (except SanDisk regular) Class 10/UHS-I that's rating... Actual real world performance does get better each model faster cards come more expensive prices. Since Amazon doesn't carry Ultra PLUS model of microSD card had to do direct comparisons between SanDisk Ultra ($34.27) Extreme ($57.95) Extreme PLUS ($67.95).As mentioned my earlier review purchased SanDisk Ultra for my Galaxy S4. My question did want to pay over $20 more for card faster than one already owned? Or could pay almost double to get SanDisk's 2nd-most fastest microSD card.The Ultra works perfectly fine for my style of usage (storing/capturing pictures & HD video movie playback) my phone. end ended up buying another SanDisk Ultra 64GB card. use my cell phone *more* than do my tablet if card good enough for my phone it's good enough for my tablet. don't own 4K HD camera anything so honestly didn't see need to get one of faster cards time.I am now proud owner of 2 SanDisk Ultra cards have 0 issues my Samsung devices.[[ ORIGINAL REVIEW - 5/1/2013 ]]I haven't had to buy microSD card long time. The last time bought one for my cell phone over 2 years ago. since my cellular contract up knew would have to get newer card addition to my new phone Samsung Galaxy S4. Reason for because knew my small 16GB microSD card wasn't going to cut it.Doing research Galaxy S4 wanted to get best card possible had decent capacity (32 GB greater). led me to find Galaxy S4 supports microSDXC Class 10 UHS-I card which fastest possible given class. Searching for specifically Amazon gave me results of only 3 vendors (as of April) makes these microSDXC Class 10 UHS-1 cards. They Sandisk (the majority) Samsung Lexar. Nobody else makes these sold Amazon.Seeing how SanDisk pretty good name out of 3 (I've used them most) decided upon SanDisk because Lexar overpriced Samsung one overpriced (as well as not eligible for Amazon Prime).But scary when filter by SanDisk get DOZENS of options. All of them have different model numbers different sizes etc. Then there's confusion of what's difference between SDHC & SDXC?SDHC vs SDXC:SDHC stand for "Secure Digital High Capacity" SDXC stands for "Secure Digital eXtended Capacity". Essentially these two cards same exception SDHC only supports capcities up to 32GB formated FAT32 file system. The SDXC cards formatted with exFAT file system. If use SDXC card device must support file system otherwise may not recognizable and/or have to reformat card to FAT32.FAT32 vs exFAT:The differences between two file systems means FAT32 has maximum file size of 4GB limited by file system. exFAT otherhand supports file sizes up to 2TB (terabytes). The only need to know really it's possible your device doesn't support exFAT. If that's case reformat to FAT32. REMEMBER FORMATTING ERASES ALL DATA!To clarify model numbers hopped over to SanDisk official webpage. What found there that offer two "highspeed" options for SanDisk cards. These SanDisk Extreme Pro SanDisk Ultra. SanDisk Extreme Pro a line that supports read speeds up to 95MB/sec however are SDHC only. To make things worse are currently only available 16GB & 8GB capacities. Since one of my requirements to have a lot of storage ruled these out.The remaining devices listed Amazon's search the SanDisk Ultra line. here confusion sets because SanDisk separates these cards to two different devices. Cameras & mobile devices. Is there a real difference between the two is this a marketing stunt? Unfortunately not sure do know the price difference between the two range a couple cents to a few dollars. Since wasn't sure opted for the one specifically targeted for mobile devices (just in case there is some kind of compatibility issue). To find the exact model number would go to Sandisk's webpage (sandisk.com) compare their existing product lineup. From there you get exact model numbers you can then search Amazon for these model numbers. That is how got mine (SDSDQUA-064G).As for speed tests haven't run any specific testing copying 8 GB worth of data my PC to the card literally took just a few minutes.One last note is that Amazon attaches additional characters to the end (for example SDSDQUA-064G-AFFP-A vs SDSDQUA-064G-U46A). The difference between the two is that the "AFFP-A" means "Amazon Frustration Free Packaging". Other than that these are exactly the same. If you're wondering what I got (and want to use it in your Galaxy S4) I got the SDSDQUA-064G-u46A it works charm.

column22414: No question as fast as it's rated. How fast? class "10 SDHC" means SD format HC=High Capacity Class 10 = 10MB/sec read-write. How fast 10MB per second? Class 4 most common step down (i.e. cheaper) Class 4 i.e. 4MB/sec. Class 10 2.5 times faster. Why pay difference?Digital cameras: some point number of pictures/sec HD video bottle-necked by speed of media being recorded to.Smart phones? have Samsung Note II. Quad-core processor wiz-bang yadda-yadda. Yes DO notice speed differences camera app performance (I use spreadsheet app/browser/NetFlix/Music streaming et al) noticeably FASTER. Where do think phone stores stuff to when doesn't use factory installed memory? (iPhomes don't have SD slot wouldn't own phone tablet doesn't -- believe choice computer realm)Oh yeah SanDisk is a leader pioneer the SD format (where do think the 'SD' came from?). The only other SDHC Class 10 card worthy of comparison is the Samsung brand then I might biased that one.

column23788: had bought card for my new Samsung Galaxy S3. The card about as good as can expect for price technology you're paying for.SDXC cards come formatted exFAT by default which what would have tried to format as seen if my phone supports filesystem. In addition to being faster format enabling higher transfer rates exFAT also takes up less storage space than say FAT FAT32 filesystem would - which important when considering mobile storage devices.I read several poor reviews about product starting simply stopped working after few months. While can happen regular use as has happened to me past couple 32GB SDHCs would venture to say was error use. Flash media very sensitive regards to ""hard shutdowns"". that's to say pulling it out of your device card reader without first unmounting Within 'Data Storage' menu Android phones there option to 'unmount SD card'. would recommend ALWAYS select before removing any external memory card to avoid corruption of data ultimately card itself. The reason for sudden stoppage of flash memory device's data power connectivity can easily result corruption.Transversely if have memory card plugged into card reader say SD adapter; should first ""Eject"" card. In Windows there a small icon located taskbar notification menu for ""Safely Remov[ing] Hardware Eject[ing] Media"". Select card and a notification will pop-up the card is now safe to remove. basically severs the same function as the Android 'unmount' optional will also cease any current read/write operations to avoid data device corruption.I cannot speak for how one would do on a Mac OS chances if you're using an Apple PC you don't have an Android phone."

column28308: had been using 'regular' SanDisk 32GB Micro SD card came included my HTC Thunderbolt bought 2011. The size decent never realized until upgrading how much was lacking speed.I finally got one of these to replace my old card my Galaxy S3. superb. recently got Galaxy S4 again card just about best expansion can add to most any phone.With my old MicroSD card had gotten used to just sitting there zoning out as waited patiently for my computer to transfer pictures/videos off my card to backed-up to my PC's hard drive copying some music files my PC to my card. With new card almost any single file (even hundreds of megabytes big) is an instant transfer transfers too quick to even bring up "moving" dialog box Windows 8. On my big transfers (lots of HD video files once totaling several gigabytes) have to wait I'm waiting for seconds instead of minutes.Combine excellent speed fact 64GB can hold ton of data (compared to typical storage sizes phones) have very satisfied customer. Now can procrastinate even longer occasional transfers of all my pictures videos to my PC though try not to.A lot of phones (like my S4) specify 64GB SDXC cards as maximum support so is about the best can even get for the moment unless want to pay almost double for SanDisk's Extreme cards. Unless you have money to burn I think these a much better value diminishing returns certainly kick beyond price point. perhaps my next phone will support 4K HD video onto 256GB cards I will yet again need to upgrade my card's capacity speed... Anyway bottom line this product: AWESOME."

column30209: tested several UHS-1 compliant devices found write speed 11-12 MByte/Second. column30759: purchased card Sandisk packaging so am pretty sure genuine. tested various programs web apparently can detect whether fakes not. one turned out to real Sandisk card. The card came formatted FAT32.I read web about these micro SDs apparently not as fast as full SD card version. borrowed my brothers Sandisk 32gb full SD card to make comparison tests. Here my official/unofficial test results using DiskBench V2.6.2.0 H2testw 1.4 test. will give results as ""overall"" result because after testing these cards over over speed writes reads results get mixed varied to big degree... much larger than expected numerous tests showed me ""general"" trend. The trend full SD cards do write faster than MicroSD card. also remember microSD had to put into adapter to do test my PC while fullSD card put into computer reader directly.These are just my averages but:Small file writes:Both SD cards wrote close to 10mb/sec. The microSD less consistent tests sometimes dropped to 8mb/sec.Small file reads:Both SD cards read close to 20 mb/sec their fastest.Large file copies to card:MicroSD wrote 3.5mb/sec while fullSD wrote about 4mb/secLarge file reads copies card:MicroSD 10mb/sec while fullSD read about 14mb/sec.My conclusion:My tests by no means official for card showed much variance dependent file size of the reads writes the fullSD card faster many cases equal to microSD most cases. The small file writes reads showed are similar enough. my only concern large file writes.... 3.5 mb/sec good enough for rapid photography high pixel camera? don't know. have had no problem using these cards with H264 movie capture for hours. am surprised 3.5 mb/sec is enough.Also never during the huge file copies to the card did get any noticeable heating of the card itself by touch even for hour. noticed it has been complaint many people the web some stating felt they might burn themselves. copied files that took more than hour with no noticeable temperature change other than perhaps a couple of degrees. Of course was a PC not installed a camera.The card performs well for video work appears to meet many other tests performed by other people. never saw a read close to 30 mb/sec... they consistent 20 mb/sec the highest performance.I would get the card again if the price were right."

column31661: The Nexus One listed as supporting maximum of 32GB an SDCard.Based reports elsewhere took out my 32GB card put 64GB card powered up phone.The phone reported card defective notification.I pulled down notifications tapped notification issued report. offered to format card.I would note have Clockwork Recovery ROM Manager app installed my rooted (CM7 Android 2.3) N1.After tapping notification phone formatted card. All went well. Since had neglected to move my RootExplorer file manager off SD card prior to putting new card not able to check directly phonethat entire 64GB available. as turned out was.While doing above had been using Winzip to make copy of contents of my 32GB card to my PC (using USB adapter). When completedI powered down phone put new 64GB card PC using Micro SD adapter came card USB adapter for adapter.It showed about 60GB (the usual for 64GB card guess).Interestingly some files (mainly folders) related to clockworkmod had been placed SD card during formatting which shows where formatting codeprobably came from. Take note: if do *not* have ROM Manager / Clockworkmod your phone your mileage may well vary. If have root would suggest obtainingROM Manager Google Play prior to doing above. Anyway deleted those files so they wouldn't conflict any of old files was aboutto copy.I then unzipped the saved contents of my old card onto the new card.Then put the new card the N1 powered up. worked perfectly right away.Root Explorer showed about 60GB of capacity (of which about 30 was used by me - really needed card!).Tried out Spotify Premium played fine saved files had been the old card were now transferred to the new card. Other thanRoot Explorer haven't tried any other apps yet am expecting good news based the experience thus far!I tried a full backup using ROM Manager it apparently worked without incident.So based the above I would recommend card for the Nexus One! What a break to get another 30 GB an aging phonethat nonetheless still one of the best phones ever.Caveat: Keep mind that I just unwrapped this thing and have used it for all of two hours.

Since then have inserted back camera reformatted (like always should) bam one photo good after failure every single time. now have 64GB card capable of taking storing ONE PHOTO time before must run ""fix file system"" my computer.Don't waste your money card over priced not faster than other cards have zero longevity. may one off problem created by proprietary format exFAT makes card loser more to point poor customer who buys it.UPDATE JULY 2012After contacting sandisk have offered RMA first must verify have not tried to ""recover"" ""wipe"" data card must ship my expense to Taiwan. have since emailed them reply to requested information (date of purchase photos of card packaging ect) told them data their my data if could have accessed card would have wiped why should give them my information stored card? That makes me less than happy am guessing want to discourage returns. Who would want to send data to company not knowing who will access what will do information contained? would have wiped card unreadable unable to format unable to do anything. will send to them hoping information destroyed along bad card.Sandisk asking whole lot of your customers since this card has gone bad have had several other cards them go bad as well seems to whole lot of cards being shipped die very short time periods. used to love their products their older flash drives great still using micro cruzer 6 years old going strong. have not had one single microSD card this company last more than three months since moved to Philippines. Either send their junk to Philippines have dropped QC their business model to create higher profit margins.**UPDATE 2**After emailing Sandisk expressing my displeasure having to return item intact so can ""assess"" card look at/recover what ever personal information may have been stored card they rescinded. can only assume they want to get card back to verify it is bad make sure not trying to get free card out of them which can understand. With their faith restoring gesture will not remove them my list of companies to avoid. just hope they get better at QC. returned another defective card to the retailer yesterday only to find out you MUST have the original packaging for a replacement. I was lucky to still have one of my packages but since I bought several of the cards I am not sure if I gave them the matching package for the card I returned.I would suggest if you are me and have several devices (2 DSLR's galaxy Tab2 galaxy Note 2 SII LG-P920) you find a way to mark each card/package and keep the package the case the card should go bad. column32618: SanDisk makes lot of claims about card some of them questionable. own two while high-capacity/low-price certainly makes them useful they're not answer to all of my recording needs. First of all do not use GoPro Hero 3 (or later model). Despite SanDisk's claims these cards cannot handle demands of true HD recording. GoPro removed from their list of recommended cards because caused cameras to lock up turn off. Even myCanon VIXIA HF10 Flash Memory High Definition Camcorder--technology which over 10 years old--the SanDisk Ultra card does not meet requirements for shooting FXP mode (1920x1080 17Mbps) even though camera says only class 4 required. firmware update to GoPro 'fixed' issue for Hero 3 Hero 3+ cameras did so by throttling recording speed for cards i.e. lowering quality of recording slightly.Those shortcomings aside SanDisk Ultra can shoot XP+ mode (1440 x 1080) Vixia HF10 works with all of settings of aContourROAM Waterproof HD 1080P. Is it "water-proof temperature proof X-ray proof shock proof"? can't say. The ContourROAM a waterproof camera so even non-waterproof cards safe for submersion if they're housing. The Ultra has functioned 10 weather after being dropped so there's validity to claim of it being temperature- shock-proof. guess I'll find out whether it's x-ray-proof the next time go through the airport...

column32893: got my wife Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 10.1 for Christmas took awhile for her to start figuring out all things can do. Once did led of course to her wanting to watch movies it. That my signal to spring into action if wanted to prevent her running wild buying ""digital copies"" of every movie we already have DVD Blu-Ray. You can't play DVD Blu-Ray movies device CAN use your computer's DVD Blu-Ray drive commonplace third-party software to convert movies format into "".mp4"" and/or several other types of video files CAN played this tablet.Since this particular tablet capable of playing high-definition video (screen resolution 1280 x 800 pixels) we want to use ALL of high-def capability my conversion files tend to pretty large (average 5 to 10GB per movie) way too big to stored tablet's limited internal memory. That's where tablet's microSD slot this SanDisk flash memory comes in. make HUGE mp4's store them separately 1.5 terabyte drive then load as many of them as can this chip which shows up tablet as separate memory source. Then all have to do pull up one of movie files card hit play. You can use device's standard video player get app more controls.Watching high-def video tablet that's streaming data memory card (rather than tablet's internal memory) requires memory card very high ""read speed"" this SanDisk card's ""Class 10"" rating fills bill. That's difference between cheaper microSD that's primarily designed for simple data storage microSD that's designed for higher active transfer/read speeds. The ""Class 10"" designation generally means subject card will transfer data a MINIMUM rate of 10MB per second. SanDisk ""Ultra"" card capable of transferring data speeds of up to 30MB per second depending speed of device you're using other particulars of way you're using device.""Frustration free packaging"" means chip SD adapter plastic case comes a little sealed cardboard envelope a pull tab opener. card comes pre-formatted for Android my use of Galaxy Tab 3 for watching high-def .mp4 movies has thus far been flawless.Finally don't let yourself get burned by counterfeiters trying to save a buck. While pricing memory tends to fluctuate Amazon's current pricing this card VERY competitive any/all vendors out there selling GENUINE SanDisk ""Ultra"" memory. Buy Amazon other trustworthy vendor because just learned hard way these memory cards being counterfeited in huge numbers that counterfeiters placing SanDisk labeling/packaging inferior generic microSD selling bogus chips Ebay anywhere else can. bought THREE Amazon after got burned by a Chinese seller Ebay. The counterfeit packaging labeling good enough to fool me until actually tried one of the chips in the Galaxy Tab 3 the write speed (that the amount of time takes to transfer files ONTO the microSD card) dramatically worse than the speed of a genuine SanDisk ""Ultra"" card and the read speed totally inadequate for playing movies the Galaxy Tab 3. may never have figured it out all if didn't already have one other genuine SanDisk ""Ultra"" which to compare the fakes.If you want the best most reliable memory for the microSD slot your shiny new Android device look no further this is it."

column36765: My review little backwards… thought most relevant should go first.WARNING: ONLY BUY THIS CARD ON SALE!The *typical* price since summer 2013 about $24 for 32 GB about $48 for 64 GB. DO NOT pay any more than can actually pay less if have luxury of time / patience.The lowest (non-lightning) price hit about $18.00 for 32GB $35 for 64GB early December. basically buy when price hits $20 less 64 nears $40.00.From December 2013 to January 2014 watched these cards change price an almost daily basis. They initially went sale for about $17.95 $34.95 for 32 64 respectively. watched them slowly increase price random dips peaks for month. On January 6th 2014 still show as "Best Deal Amazon" for "7 more days" they highest price point since last summer -- higher than have *ever* payed for these cards! don't let "Best Deals" section deceive at $27/$50 these NOT "deal" terms of price.Okay here's my actual "review" of these great SDXC cards.****I have tried variety of MicroSDXC cards so far Samsung Ultra UHS1 best -- price can't beat -- for all most important reasons: speed capacity reliability durability.I have not had single failure use these cards my Nook HD+ Nexus 7 2013 (via USB) my Canon 5D Mark II (with converter) MacBook Pro (In card slot). They're durable waterproof can use same card all these devices without reformatting. even had one go through wash I still use for pictures.For technically inclined I have cards *both* Clockwork Mod bootloader (for Nook HD+) MagicLantern firmware for my Canon EOS 5D II the same card. I can pull from the Nook shoot pictures the camera look at the results the Nook by pulling the card out of one device and placing the other. should possible any SDXC/SDHC card it turns out the Samsung UHS1 the only card found works reliably. Some cards won't boot because they're too slow too finicky all my Samsung UHS1s work great (the 64GB will not boot the Nook no 64GB card will).I keep my eyes open for price drops these cards because they've performed so well for me. Samsung also has a newer faster card its price-point hovers somewhere north of "prohibitive" so I still stick these. And that's good news regardless because as the new card increases its market share these should drop even further in price.
column36767: Watch Price - Great Card Often on Sale

column37908: have tested dozens of SDHC micro-SDHC cards. One disturbing trend noticed that: speed class rating for micro-SDHC typically inflated. For example 'class-10' rating means card must deliver sequential write speed of least 10MB/s. somehow class-10 microSDHC cards always slower than class-10 SDHC card same manufacturer. Case point: thePNY 32 GB microSDHC Card (P-SDU32G10-EFS2)claims to 'class-10' yet can only write 8.6MB/s maximum while full-sizePNY P-SDHC16G10achieved 13.4MB/s according to CrystalDiskMark v3.01.ThisSanDisk Ultra 32 GB microSDHC Class 10 UHS-1 card (SDSDQUA-032G-U46A) however proves to exception. achieved sequential write speed of over 10MB/s according to two different benchmark programs (11.8MB/s ""CrystalDiskMark"" 10.6MB/s ""H2testw v1.4""). faster than all my other microSDHC cards including two 'class-10' cards fromPNYandPolaroid.A closer look file transfer speed using ""Flash Memory Toolkit"" revealed another nice surprise: For writing small files Sandisk Ultra microSDHC card performed as well as its full-size counterpart theSanDisk Ultra SDHC (SDSDU-032G-AFFP). In contrast all my other class-10 microSDHC cards perform poorly while writing smaller files. See benchmark results uploaded to 'Customer Images' for details.When use memory card digital camera to record HD video needs to store a huge video file each session. That means its sequential write speed most critical. When used a tablet a smart phone however card's random write speed for small files more important. That's why such applications Sandisk microSDHC will perform faster than PNY Polaroid cards even though also rated as 'class-10'.[Bottom Line]As of writing Sandisk Ultra microSDHC card ia actually priced lower than other class-10 cards PNY Polaroid. makes Sandisk best value - especially if need honest class-10 performance across all platforms.[Side Notes]- Do not confuse Sandisk Ultra card withSanDisk Mobile Ultra microSDHC (SDSDQY-032G-U46A). The latter rated for class-6 only.- The size of '32GB' card 29.7GB according to my computer. actually normal because computer people count one Gig as ""2 to power 30"" which 7.3% larger than one billion. 29.7GB translates to 31.9 billion bytes which is '32GB' according to marketing people.[Update Feb 4 2013]1. Amazon combined Sandisk Ultra 32GB 64GB cards same product page. Please beware your intended appliance must compatible 'SDXC' order to used 64GB version. My original review refers to 32GB 'SDHC' version.2. There two part numbers for same card. If start Amazon product page select 'Retail Packaging' you'll see the part number of SDSDQUA-032G-U46A. if click 'Frustration Free Package' the part number changes to SDSDQU-032G-AFFP-A.[Update Oct 5 2013]The Sandisk microSDHC card works great my new Samsung Galaxy S3 without the need for reformat (the default format is FAT32)[Update Dec 26 2013]My old test results limited by the card reader USB 2.0 port used. re-tested the Sandisk UHS1 micro card using theTranscend RDF5 Card Readerconnected to USB 3.0 port. Here are the results 'CrystalDiskMark 3.01 x64':- Sequential Read speed = 40.0MB/s (was 34.8MB/s when connected to USB 2.0 port)- Sequential Write speed = 13.1MB/s (was 12.6MB/s when connected to USB 2.0 port)"

column41294: The primary reason for buying extra capacitySanDisk Ultra 64 GB microSDXC Class 10card to use inSamsung Galaxy Tab 2 (10.1-Inch Model GT-P5113)and am happy to share can get to work flawlessly after some initial glitches. (Read below)Firstly need to aware Samsung Tablet Model GT-P5113 currently runs Android OS 4.1.1 Kernel 3.0.31-523998 Build number JRO03C.P5113UECLK7.(Jelly Bean) My experiences shared level of Android OS your experiences may vary depending what version of OS are running. The SanDisk Ultra 64 GB microSDXC card purchased Amazon (Retail Packaging) gets recognized fine however when tablet's Media Device A.K.A 'MTP' application attempts to talk your PC via USB cable Tablet simply reboots! after card presented to PC. - Really strange indeed!This baffled me for couple of hours. Firstly attempted to format card (exFAT) PC formatted fine. After I attempted to use tablet to see same behavioral oddity of instantaneous reboot of tablet as 'MTP' application tries to communicate PC. made me investigate issue further I determined root cause fact SANDISK now seen to factory format card 'exFAT' also somehow seen to include 'offset' of 16MB beginning of card which shows up as 16MB unallocated region initial sectors card under windows disk management tool.The solution to get rid of 'unallocated' 16MB partition card. You could do PC might require some windows command line experience using 'diskpart' utility what not I do not want to confuse people process. For most novice users The process should very simple Just insert card the tablet use the 'native' SD Card format tool under 'settings' Android OS 4.1.1 has it will get rid of 16MB partition happily remount Now after this simple process the 'MTP' application works fine with PC to transfer files to the SD card without any strange reboot phenomenon.Not sure why SANDISK formats their Class 10 card this fashion (They never did it with their class 6 cards earlier) there's gotta some technical explanation for why include 16MB partition that only SANDISK can give. In the end if reformat the card in the tablet (Which defaults to exFAT) the card seen to work fine.Bottomline:-----------This an awesome 64GB capacity MicroSD card reputed manufacturer for budget minded people gets the job done beautifully. The read write speeds are adequate enough for most AudioVideo & picture file formats in a tablet. The glitch mentioned above forced me to give *Four* stars instead of *Five* stars let that not stop you from making a decision to buy it.Highly recommended!Cheers!

column43097: The description quite confusing - says same time class 10 which means should not expect write speed higher than 10mb/sec at same time says UHS-1 which means 30mb/sec write speed. The truth as usually somewhere middle close to lower end. have dedicated high speed PCI-E cardreader which use for chip benchmarking. card showed 12mb/sec sequental write speed 34mb/sec sequental read speed. UHS-1 "true" only for read operations meaning if wanted card to speed-up your digital camera speed photography - you've made wrong choice. Just for reference this cardTranscend 16 GB Class 10 microSDHC Flash Memory Card TS16GUSDHC10has sequental write speed of 17mb/sec sequental read speed of 24mb/sec. As you see the cheaper transcend has average 40% faster write speeds!

column46295: NOTE: please read last update (scroll to bottom) - leaving review as 1 star as appears to help others who purchased had similar experience.I give SanDisk 5 stars for customer service 1 star for product (for those manufactured past) For those newly manufactured products contain software ROM fix I'd give product 5 stars.To all those who purchased card due to all great reviews.... then used Galaxy S4 (GS4) smartphone for storage solution to problem not one can solve without returning card to SanDisk for replacement under warranty. Believe me tried everything Google searches returned as solutions... formatting as exFAT formatting GS4 then copying data to card while phone etc.... nothing worked... so now please stop pulling out your hair hopefully will get same result which hope to get soon (just RMA'd will send back tomorrow for free replacement under warranty).The problem (As confirmed SanDisk customer support rep when asked specifically asked him):- When used GS4 card will unmount itself inadvertently (may true only for cards manufactured before ROM patch described below implemented manufacturing). can cause data to become corrupt (luckily not my experience) / can frustrating as most of us saving 13 MP camera pictures to card (or MP4 movies stop middle of movie) unmounts when view picture gallery worse right when take picture (this issue experienced).- SanDisk knows about issue. Again SANDISK KNOWS ABOUT THE ISSUE AND WILL REPLACE YOUR CARD. Call them (info below) WILL take care of under warranty. They have good name for reason want to keep (sorry SanDisk about 1 star thought way to get message out to those searching for solution)- The customer rep told me SanDisk tried to work Samsung to resolve issue Samsung refused to acknowledge problem exists card some of their phones (especially their flagship GS4 phones).- The customer rep told me to their knowledge card works fine regular cameras (not Samsung GS4 phones cameras obviously) even worked fine some phones HTC etc. could accommodate 64 GB cards. Hence 5 star ratings others.- The solution SanDisk came up to write patch into ROM of card itself to specifically address issue Samsung GS4 phones (and maybe other Samsung phones GS3). assured new card would get would work flawlessly. will see about 3 weeks.- purchased my card Amazon June 2013 so ones currently being manufactured one should get will have new patch. However as SanDisk manufactures batches (like most of industry) old batches of "unpatched" cards obviously exist warehouses.- asked about software patch could download told it's not possible... hence "hard coded patch" card's ROMSo... how to take care of problem....After speaking SanDisk US customer support (link info below) what learned did.Go to SanDisk site1) [...]2) call consumer products support (this US no.) 1-866-SANDISK (726-3475)3) Tell them card unmounting itself your GS4 (I assume also problem experienced by GS3 owners too)4) They will then confirm your information approve your return (10-15 min approval window by mine basically instantaneously) then send emails UPS return label instructions.5) BTW also asked if had magnifying glass to ID serial no. card didn't couldn't read myself (those numbers super small printed into plastic... don't me? take look yourself.) told rep couldn't read them said no problem would process without serial no. assume because send new replacement card only when they receive your card send in. Makes sense.Well that's Problem (hopefully) solved. Let's see 2-3 weeks. The rep was super nice about seemed they all too familiar problem. KUDOS TO SANDISK FOR TAKING CARE OF IT... however would nice if there was some type of communication / notice of issue besides Google info sources forums etc. spent hours maybe couple of days total hours worth thinking was issue my phone / my data transfer. oh well that's how goes.I hope review helps some of out there same problem as me. GOOD LUCK!!(btw I'd give card 5 stars if problem was solved patched ROM of newer cards as data transfer speeds awesome card (tested transferring data via card reader hooked to my computer)... if data transfer / remaining mounted GS4 issue never existed (pre-patch of ROM of course))UPDATE: 08/17/2013 - All went well return of the SanDisk Storage card. UPS shipping took about 2 days when sent SanDisk verified the warranty claim 1 day later 5 hours later same day my replacement card had been shipped. waiting the new card now expect to test out soon (early next week). will update the post after testing out the new card. Just as reference been using 32GB Micro SD HC SanDisk card the GS4 since having shipped the 64GB card. Obviously it's different card not the Micro SD XC kind. Other than bit slower access speeds to the card zero problems.... well if don't count it's basically filled up hence why the 64GB option great the GS4. proves the point the problem the early build Micro SD XC 64GB cards.I'm happy to see my review has helped some others out there. Good luck to your warranty claim. my experience SanDisk customer support has been excellent so far.Update: 08/21/2013 - Received the new replacement SanDisk Storage card few days ago (shipping back to me once they agreed was defective was short time window). Have had running the Galaxy S4 for few days now without any jumps stutters card unloading the middle of picture video taking. Card seems to work flawlessly as the SanDisk Rep mentioned would. One would it's such a short time to test after a few days of use if were not fixed already would have dismounted the first 45 minutes... that's how often how fast was occurring. so would seem the problem is solved. The new SD card makes the phone even more responsive when moving between pictures the gallery performing other tasks copying files to the card. Thanks SanDisk! Unless update review by next week will know the problem has been fixed.Good luck to those similar problems as we now know how to get fixed thanks to SanDisks great responsive customer service.Update: 08/31/2013 - is the last update to review to "close the loop". The new replacement card SanDisk has been running flawlessly for about 2 weeks now. have not experienced any of the initial problems. SanDisk did fix the issues the new batch of cards.Update: 12/09/2013 - The card has been running in my GS4 flawlessly since replacing around Aug 21st. Pretty good track record so far (~ 3.5 months) so appears to fixed the newly manufactured (replacement) cards.For those have left comments should change the rating upwards now the issue is fixed (see my addition the beginning of this review)... When searching for a solution to a problem a purchased product most people start the 1 star reviews to see what others have experienced. is especially true for products a lot of reviews (this is what I did in the beginning this product). Therefore I think leaving 1 star adding the comments at the beginning should clarify the review.Thanks to review commenter "Da Shocker" for his input. I think he sums up very well when it comes to the value of files stored media this:"One more thing.. to those not happy the one star rating by this person go ahead buy one. Take tons of pics vids save some music there then when the card crashes come back and give it a five star. card cost $50-$100 pictures a vacation family event priceless.. "

column47790: Once cut pry your way through Sandisk's packaging will rewarded nicely-made high-performing MicroSD UHS1 flash memory. comes formatted to SD.org's standards FAT32 so it's ready to go for most applications. My single gripe about product have omitted usual small plastic box holds card adapter. use those! Since frequently switch cards between uses frequently have them storage those little boxes very useful. It's way too easy to lose MicroSD.Anyway results ATTO disk benchmark:Settings (anticipating digicam use): Total length 64MB Overlapped I/O QD=4 (but never exceeds 1)Segment Size Kbytes Read/Write Kbyte/secSize Write Read.5 9904 163431 14555 170332 13454 273244 14194 353378 15065 3985316 14154 4062932 14277 4295764 13212 44291128 17567 44247256 16209 44442512 15391 444421024 17408 444422048 16229 44442[Sorry for ugly table Amazon does not support consecutive spaces including alt-255 embedded tabs]This very fast for MicroSD. It's not quite up to what Sandisk achieves full size UHS1 SD cards can write over twice speed those are electronically more complex cards. The Micro form factor likely doesn't permit additional hardware to achieve speeds comparable to larger cards. Note read speed lot faster than what Sandisk promises. (Note also that will NOT achieve these speeds a USB2 reader. You will need either a USB3 built-in PCIe reader to get accurate results. do not complain to me if you use a USB2 reader don't achieve these speeds.)In any event you'd hard-pressed to find anything faster.My personal experience Sandisk products very good. That I've never had anything fail me. Given the very reasonable prices of these rate them as Highly Recommended.

column48615: Maybe there nothing can done way technology time to me seems 64GB SD cards have limited uses at time because formatted whats called "exFAT32" instead of standard FAT32 to get 64GB 32GB card. After receiving my card inserting into my new android tablet Jelly Bean recognized did show had 59GB available. then removed card tablet inserted into my computers Win7 Vista tried to transfer files photos videos my laptop to card WOULD NOT TRANSFER! After some research internet appeared card had to reformatted new "exFAT32" to standard FAT32. All my files created Win XP Win Vista - FAT32. also have Win7 machine recently purchased can easily move all types of files between all machines memory cards flash drives could not transfer any files to card any computer as long as card was formatted exFAT32. had read internet about reformatting cards working. My Win7 machine does not even have option to format to standard FAT32 only has NSTF exFAT32. My older computers have older FAT32 format option took my Vista computer Dual Core processor 1 hours to reformat card to FAT32. After reformatting was able to easily transfer my files photos videos my XP Vista computers BUT not Win7 computer. The card works my tablet am able to access use all files transferred to card FAT32 my Vista computer tablet. BUT after reformatting now the card only has 27GB of space available so was essentially reformatted the 64GB card into 32GB card. will keep the card because have a lot of work into reformatting transferring files hopefully the future can reformat it again back to exFAT32 if when exFAT32 catches OS made can seamlessly use files created both FAT32 exFAT32. seems to a good card works well certain situations my advice do your research what have how will use the card because not simply a big GB card can used for everything every device unless ALL your files photos videos will created exFAT32 there are some real draw backs to card might better off just buying multiple lower GB cards if really need much storage space in a Micro SD card. Or perhaps cards you already own can reformatted into exFAT32 double the capacity if your computer has the exFAT32 reformat option. have not tried it based my experience the last few days it seems it would work if exFAT32 works for you. I gave 3 stars because it does work but I feel Sandisk not fully explaining how are getting 64GB out of this card and the possible problems a consumer might have it is misleading advertising.

column49879: There a speed penalty if exfat used as oppose to NTFS.Using ATTO formatted as exfat:read speed = ~45MBswrite speed = ~15MBsUsing ATTO formatted as NTFS:read speed = ~45MBswrite speed = ~17MBsWith exfat write speed actually fluctuates as transfer size increases. using NTFS speed consistent.Tested Lenovo T530 using built SD card reader.

column50418: Monday November 26 2012I put Galaxy S3 without formatting restarted phone showed 59.4g GB of space. transferred all files old 16 GB card then moved all my music to card phone connected to my computer by USB cord. Still lots of space left various music players seem to see all music.Tuesday November 27 2012The card didn't show up phone afternoon. No message no songs to play no card according to everything could check phone. restarted phone got notification SD card corrupt needed formatting would loose all data card. restarted phone again without formatting card came up had never been missing. am writing Thursday 11/29 have not had another issue card.December 6Well don't know what to think. The whole point of getting large card to have my music my phone not have to stream cloud. tried several music players went PowerAmp because of good reviews could specify folder to play from. PowerAmp looking for folder /mnt/extSdCard/Music playing songs all subfolders. PowerAmp tells me folder not available.The card has gone missing one other time restarting phone fixed problem.Today PowerAmp would not play when got home found Music folder gone. also had Ringtones folder it also gone. Now may not sharpest saw shed know did not delete those folders. The card had other folders not those two so it had not been reformatted.I am starting to problem Galaxy S3. had 16 GB FAT32 card phone had been my previous HTC phone. That card not large enough to held my music so don't know if it disappearing not. wish combination of phone 64GB card more reliable don't know where problem lies.I lowered stars 4 to 3 don't know if problem card phone both. All know do not seem to playing well together.December 7There notification phone morning that SD card was corrupted needed to formatted. restarted phone several times got notification each time. reformatted SD card using phone step don't have tried yet.December 8Another MINOR problem have that message counter gets stuck 1 when have no new messages. The only fix have found to restart phone. That happened morning got corrupted card message again restarted again card came up OK.December 11So files card keep disappearing. The card mounted the phone shows the correct free memory PowerAmp file directory programs do not see any files the card. restart the phone the files come back. Very strange. played music off all day today without problem then evening all the files disappeared again. Restarted the phone all well again.December 15My phone upgraded to 4.1.1 yesterday the same issues remain. is crap shoot as to if music will play. take lot of photos use the service Zenfolio to store display them. have an app that syncs Zenfolio keeps phone size version of the photos my phone. set this app to store the photos the Samsung SD card have similar issues with it when the data the phone goes away. morning the SD card came up as corrupt again after restart to get the data back. took total of 3 restarts to get the music photos back.December 18I have been trying to play music stored on this card today my phone has reset several times. Very frustrating. I ordered SanDisk 32 GB Mobile microSDHC Flash Memory Card SDSDQ-032G-AFFP today for about $25.00 I'll see if I have the same issues. Very disappointing.December 28I purchased installed theSanDisk 32 GB Mobile microSDHC Flash Memory Card SDSDQ-032G-AFFPand copied all the files from the 64GB card to the new 32GB card. No formatting no fuss no muss. I have not had phone reset since have played music through Bluetooth for hours in the car have viewed photos. Everything just works. Half the memory what I have is always available and the phone works good trade off. I am still disappointed that the 64GB did not work with the SG3. I have purchased aelago Mobile Nano II USB 2.0 microSDHC Flash Memory Card Reader (Black)to use the 64GB MicroSDHC card as a thumb drive.

column50517: Hi:I ordered two card arrived next day even faster than Prime. Unfortunatey 64gb MicroSD card designed to only work ex-fat. If you're ex-fat fan don't ever plan to change card for you. been able to take all of previous 64gb MicroSD cards ordered put them an adapter format them my Windows 7 desktop. NTSF fan find to much more stable tablets.With other cards aren't intentionally crippled can format card to NTSF Monday ex-fat Tuesday Fat32 Wednesday. It's ex-fat highway for SanDisk.You can use EaseUS Partition Master to format card to Fat32 for devices such as cameras mp3 players many many many others don't support ex-fat. That being said only get one shot. Once it's formatted into Fat32 attempting to format back to Exfat NTSF hoses card. couldn't reformat to NTSF no matter what tried. Once again don't bother trying to format your computer ex-fat only choice.Any card needs special utility to format to anything other than ex-fat shouldn't supported. Don't buy it! It's designed to fail.Shame you Sandisk!Update 9/24/12:***************************I spoke Sandisk technical support confirmed Sandisk Ultra 64gb MicroSd cards not compatible Android 4.0 above. would for Class 10 SanDisk Ultra 64 GB microSDXC Class 10 UHS-1 Memory Card 30MB/s Adapter SDSDQUA-064G-U46A as well as SanDisk 64GB Mobile Ultra MicroSDXC Class 10 UHS-1 30MB/s Memory Card SD Adapter (NEW VERSION) - Retail Packaging Komputerbay SDXC USB Reader.I did not have any success formatting class 10 card EaseUS Partition Master. SanDisk recommended free utility HPUSBDISK.exe successfully downloaded from Softpedia. was unable to format card NTSF successfully converted one of cards to Fat32 for friend who wants to use SanDisk mp3 player of course not compatible ex-fat.Acting Sandisk advice am returning unopened class ten cards KomputerBay reader. spoke patient gracious tier-one tech support person party line seems consumers only use MicroSD cards phones. don't know what they're thinking: cameras mp3 players tablets adapters so on. Anyway it's known issue.I can confirm class 6 64gb MicroSD card can formatted in Windows7 back forth to most any format so after returning four class 10 cards back to class six.It's still unconscionable to deliberately design these cards to incompatible. I hope SanDisk will come up solution recall cards. Buyer beware.Update: 9/29/12**********************I received my two replacement class 6 64gb MicroSD cards took less than five minutes to open horrible packaging to perform quick format to NTSF. Done!I gave my friend Class 10 64gb MicroSD card formatted into Fat32 by HPUSBDISK.EXE he couldn't read his computer. As it turns out class 10 cards not only incompatible most devices bur also most usb card readers. Another trip across town.I can confirm the IOGEAR SD/MicroSD/MMC Card Reader/Writer GFR204SD (Green/Gray) selling on Amazon for $6.99 works. after countless hours of wasted effort my friend has a card formatted to Fat32 works a SanDisk mp3 player.Once again SanDisk has admitted these cards not compatible Androd 4.0 above that being 100% of Android tablets a majority of Android phones. These cards intentionally crippled by design.To quote a friend:"Per the SDHC standard the format is FAT32. SDXC (64 GB larger) the spec calls for exFAT. Microsoft has limited the OS to only format larger cards as exFAT will not allow FAT32. Also seems they have found a way to also block NTFS. Thus far few Android devices can read exFAT because they refuse to pay M$ for licensing of the exFAT file system. "To all masochists out there--buy card. To everyone else--unsafe any speed.

column51353: Sandisk announcement of first 128GB micro SD took internet by storm. Our phones evolved into multimedia powerhouses 5.5"-6" displays desktop grade processing power OTG support for external peripheral accessories powerful cameras more. The only missing super high capacity internal removable storage an affordable price. 128GB micro SD announcement finally filled gap supported by amazon current sale of $119 shipped question still remained if some of older smartphones will able to handle/recognize capacity. was personally curious considering original Note 2 spec was calling for support of up to 64GB only.Now about card itself. Its their Ultra edition read speeds of up 30MB/s Class 10 performance. As part of Ultra edition it's considered to waterproof temperature-proof x-ray-proof magnet-proof also shockproof. In addition to flash card itself also includes SD adapter for compatibility digital cameras also direct reading laptops/PCs support SD card.So comes verdict: IT WORKS Note 2!!! My Note 2 all stock Verizon SCH-I605 version running stock Android 4.3. checked card first an adapter my laptop then mounted on my Note 2 where was recognized a right capacity. also ran A1 SD Benchmark app (both long accurate benchmark tests) to verify success. Read/write speed not quite near 30MB/s it's still pretty good.My opinion? card takes multimedia powerhouse Note 2 to the next level!!! Now don't have to limited can store your favorite albums FLAC audio format have a small library of your favorite movies stored permanently take more high def videos so on. Just always stay up to date with backups. If flash card fails will covered under warranty your pictures videos will lost forever.

(I would their customer service dept. would stay top of these posts because found HUGE issue)On my THIRD card did some research. For whatever reason for SD card to work must formatted as a FAT 32 NOT exFAT. BUT...(this rub)...windows only allows for formatting either to exFAT NTSF...(at first thought was adult swim reference).....so....that sucks....this means that can't use this card because can't format properly. wait..there's more....there a super easy fix....any idiot can do it.....from start to finish took me all of 45 seconds (after reading instructions)...and ta-duh.....now micro SD card works fine. Thank-you Amazon for your excellent return policy..(super fast super easy super friendly)...BUT your live customer service should know about this. I can't fault operator...she was nice..seemed genuinely concerned tried to make right)...ok.. no more stalling..here address of the youtube video. link to website in the description.[...] ...link to website in description. I used all defaults worked perfect. search youtube - convert fat32"

column53322: Most mobile devices tablets of any count state limit to their sd storage 32GB...but few of those can do read sd cards are fact larger than this. would suggest anyone thinks need space beyond those stated limits of their device do quick search line for their particular MAKE Model cellphone tablet to see what size SD's others have been successful using. Once have found out that can fact use such SD...go search online for HDD Raw Copy Tool HDD GURU...and will allow to make image of your old SD to apply to new SD and/or even make backup of one's SD. Since SD drives are different sizes when image applied to larger...you will need to use partition manager such as MiniTool partition wizard (which free for home use) resize partition of larger drive. will allow to take advantage of whole drive space. love the upgrade added space...can't go wrong price for a class 10 SD of this size.
